content: The "Family Caregiver Support and Protection Act of 1996" establishes respite care services under Medicare, providing support for caregivers. The "Family Caregiver Support and Protection Act of 1996" establishes respite care services under Medicare, providing support for caregivers. Respite care services include companion services, homemaker services, personal assistance, community day services, and temporary care in a licensed facility, provided on a short-term basis by qualified individuals or entities. The Secretary consults with service providers' organizations to establish standards for respite care services. The term 'respite care services' excludes services provided after 120 hours in a 12-month period. An eligible individual is someone with functional limitations who relies on a caregiver without financial compensation for at least 3 months. An individual with functional limitations is certified if they are unable to perform daily activities without assistance for at least 90 days, require supervision due to cognitive impairment, or have a disability similar to a specified level. The activities of daily living for individuals with functional limitations include eating, toileting, transferring, bathing, dressing, and continence. Respite care services will be paid on an hourly basis, and certification for functional limitations does not have to be performed only by a physician. The amendment to Section 1862(a) of the Act allows for respite care services to be provided to individuals after 120 hours of such services in a 12-month period. The effective date for these changes is January 1, 1997. SEC. 3. Treatment of long-term care services as medical care. The text discusses the amendment to the definition of medical care to include qualified long-term care services for chronically ill individuals. The amendment expands medical care to cover qualified long-term care services for chronically ill individuals certified by a licensed health care practitioner as unable to perform daily activities without assistance for at least 90 days. The amendment expands medical care to cover qualified long-term care services for chronically ill individuals certified by a licensed health care practitioner as unable to perform daily activities without assistance for at least 90 days. The term "activities of daily living" includes specific tasks that individuals must be unable to perform in order to qualify for this coverage. The term 'activities of daily living' includes tasks like eating, toileting, transferring, bathing, dressing, and continence. 'Substantial assistance' for these activities can include verbal reminding or physical cuing. 'Maintenance or personal care services' refer to care that provides needed assistance for disabilities of chronically ill individuals, including protection from health and safety threats. The term 'licensed health care practitioner' includes physicians, registered nurses, social workers, or individuals meeting specific requirements. The amendments in this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
